group_works.title: L'Arrivee = The Arrival
group_works.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio

results.title: L'Arrivee = The Arrival
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description:
‘L’Arrivee’ is Tscherkassky’s second homage to the Lumiere-brothers. First you see the arrival of the film itself, which shows the arrival of a train at a station. But that train collides with a second train, causing a violent crash, which leads us to an unexpected third arrival, the arrival of a beautiful woman, the happy-end.

Reduced to two minutes, ‘L’Arrivee’ gives a brief, but exact summary of what cinematography (after its arrival with Lumieres train) has made into an enduring presence of our visual environment: violence, emotions. Or, as an anonymous American housewife (cited by T. W. Adorno) used to describe Hollywood’s version of life: ‘Getting into trouble and out of it again.’

results.title: Pharmaceuticals
results.creator_credit: Robert Richter, Thirteen and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Pesticides and pills for export only”.
The film presents evidence that products banned or restricted in developed countries because of the danger to humans or the environment are exported to the Third World by multinational corporations. This episode investigates the trade in toxic pharmaceuticals.

results.title: A Man's life is his own affair
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan, Brian Hannant, Gil Brealey and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personnel or People”.
An office-worker participates in a demonstration and his face is recognised by management in a front page newspaper photograph. Deals with the responsibilities of an employee towards his employer versus his rights as a citizen. Is a man free to do as he pleases outside working hours provided that it does not adversely affect his work?

results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack S. Allan, Brian Hannant, Gil Brealey and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Turnover
results.creator_credit: Gil Brealey, Donald Crombie and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personnel or People”.
Deals with the problem of how far should a supervisor delve into the personal life and problems of staff in order to help with personal problems. Cast includes Jack Thompson.

results.title: Stirring the pool
results.creator_credit: Gil Brealey, Peter Weir, Commonwealth Public Service Board and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personnel or People”.
A new typist is asked to do a job for the manager instead of the senior typist, who is not present. Afterwards the senior typist voices her resentment, causing the new girl to feel unhappy. Another typist informs the new typist that the attitude of the senior typist is not new and has caused many resignations. What is the answer to internal warfare in the typing pool? Suitable for upper secondary level.
